facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 481 of 1965 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 481 of 1965. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated April 30, 1965 of Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 447 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order, dated April 30, 1965, of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 447 of 1965.

facts.text: Last general election of members of Bhusaval Borough Municipality held in 1960 under Bombay Municipal Borough Act, 1925.

anchor.surface_text: The last general election of the, members of the Bhusaval Borough Municipality was held under the provisions of the Act in the year 1960.

facts.text: First general meeting held on February 18, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The first general meeting thereafter was held on February 18, 1961.

facts.text: Under s. 25 of the Act, life of Municipality would have expired on February 17, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Under the provisions of s. 25 of the Act. in the numbermal companyrse the life of the Municipality would have expired on February 17, 1965

facts.text: Under s. 3 of Maharashtra Act, term of Councillors extended to December 31, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: but, under s. 3 of the Maharashtra Act the term of the Councillors of the Municipality was, by fiction, extended to and inclusive of December 31, 1965.

facts.text: Appellant elected President of Municipality on July 18, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: On July 18, 1964, the appellant was elected the President of the Municipality

facts.text: On July 18, 1964, Municipality passed resolution that term of President shall be residue of term of Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: and on the same day the Municipality passed a resolution to the effect that the term of the office of the President shall be the residue of the term of office of the Municipality.

facts.text: Collector of Jalgaon issued notice on March 2, 1965 calling meeting on March 15, 1965 for electing new President.

anchor.surface_text: On the assumption that the term of the President expired on February 17, 1965, the Collector of Jalgaon issued a numberice on March 2, 1965, calling for a meeting of the Municipality on March 15, 1965, for electing a new President.

facts.text: Appellant filed application under Arts. 226 and 227 in High Court of Maharashtra against Collector's notice.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the appellant filed an application under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution in the High Court of Maharashtra for the issue of an appropriate order setting aside the numberice issued by the Collector.

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court rejected contention and dismissed petition.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the said High Court rejected that companytention and dismissed the petition. Hence the appeal.

facts.text: Appeal by certificate to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Hence the appeal. The short question in the appeal

facts.text: Government appointed Committee in July 1963 for unification of municipal acts.

anchor.surface_text: In July, 1963, Government appointed a Committee for the purpose of companysidering the question of unification of the four Municipal Acts which are at present in force in the State.

facts.text: On July 18, 1964, Municipality passed resolution recommending extension of its term beyond 4 years.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, on or about July 18, 1964, when the term of the Presitent of the Municipality was extended, the Municipality passed a resolution recommending that the term of the Municipality be extended beyond 4 years.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court order and issued writ prohibiting Collector from holding election till December 31, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, therefore, the order of the High Court is number Correct and the same is set aside. A writ will issue prohibiting the Collector from holding the election

facts.text: Councillors hold office for 4 years under s.25, extensible to not exceeding 5 years by State Government.

anchor.surface_text: Section 25 of the Act Councillors numberinated or elected at a general election under this Act, shall, save as otherwise provided in this Act, hold office for a term of four years, extensible by order of the State Government

facts.text: s.3 Maharashtra Act deems term of Councillors expiring before Dec 31, 1965 extended to that date.

facts.text: Appellant contended term extended under second proviso s.19 or by amendment of s.25.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Agarwala, learned companynsel for the appellant, companytended that the appellant would get the extended term provided in the Maharashtra Act, because in effect it was an extension under the Act within the meaning of the second proviso to s. 19 of the Act

facts.text: Respondent argued second proviso s.19 not applicable as extension not under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General, on the other hand, argued that the second proviso to s. 19 of the Act had numberapplication, for it dealt only with an extension by numberification or otherwise under the provisions of the Act

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate raises the question of the true construction of the provisions of ss. 19 and 25 of the Bombay Municipal Borough Act, 1925 Bom. Act 18 of 1925 , hereinafter called the Act, read with s. 3 of the Maharashtra Municipalities

issues.text: whether the expression the residue of the Municipality in the resolution of the Municipality, dated July 18, 1964, means the residue of the Municipality that would have been if the Maharashtra Act had not been passed or whether it should be interpreted in the context of the extended term provided by the Maharashtra Act

anchor.surface_text: The short question in the appeal is whether the expression the residue of the Municipality in the resolution of the Municipality, dated July 18, 1964, means the residue of the Municipality that would have been if the Maharashtra Act had

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General, on the other hand, argued that the second proviso to s. 19 of the Act had no application, for it dealt only with an extension by notification or otherwise under the provisions of the Act

issues.text: whether the scope of the resolution passed by the Municipality should be construed on the basis of the circumstances existing at the time the resolution was passed, i.e., previous to the election of the President

anchor.surface_text: that even if the Maharashtra Act had the effect of amending s. 25 of the Act with the result that the life of the members of the Municipality was extended by the amendment of the Act itself, it would not help the appellant as the scope of the resolution passed by the Municipality should be construed on the basis of the circumstances existing at the time the resolution was passed

issues.text: whether on July 18, 1964, when the Municipal councillors passed a resolution to the effect that the term of office of the appellant shall be the residue of the Municipality, their intention was that his term should extend only up to February 17, 1965, i.e., the date when the term of the Municipal councillors would have expired but for the statutory extension given by the Maharashtra Act

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees intention gathered from circumstances at time of resolution, but finds councillors contemplated and expected extension

arguments.claim: the second proviso to s. 19 is not attracted, as there was no order or notification issued under s. 25 extending the term

anchor.surface_text: If that be the legal effect of s. 3 of the Maharashtra Act, the second proviso is not attracted to the instant case, as there was noorder or notification issued under s. 25 or any other relevant section of the Act extending the term of the councillors fixed under s. 25 of the Act.

arguments.claim: approach the problem on the basis of the fiction that the term of the councillors prescribed under s. 25 of the Act was extended up to December 31, 1965

anchor.surface_text: Therefore for the present purpose we leave out of consideration the second proviso to s. 19 and approach the problem on the basis of the fiction that the term of the councillors prescribed under s. 25 of the Act was extended up to December 31, 1965.

arguments.claim: the intention of the Municipality can be gathered only from the circumstances, statutory or otherwise existing at the time when the resolution was passed and on the express terms of the said resolution

anchor.surface_text: The intention of the Municipality can be gathered only from the circumstances, statutory or otherwise existing at the time when the resolution was passed and on the express terms of the said resolution. Under s. 19 of the Act, the Municipality can fix the term of office of the President between one and four years

arguments.claim: councillors contemplated extension of municipality term, as per s.19 proviso, govt committee July 1963, and own resolution July 18, 1964 recommending extension

anchor.surface_text: In July, 1963, Government appointed a Committee... Indeed, on or about July 18, 1964... the Municipality passed a resolution recommending that the term of the Municipality be extended beyond 4 years.

arguments.claim: use of elastic expression 'residue' indicates intention not limited to then-existing term but including possible extension

anchor.surface_text: With the knowledge of such a possible extension, when the members used the elastic expression residue, it is not reasonable to attribute to them the intention that they meant only the residue of the term available to them at that time. If that was their intention they would have prescribed a definite date

arguments.claim: term of President should synchronize with the life of the Municipality existing or extended; High Court order set aside, writ prohibiting election till Dec 31, 1965

anchor.surface_text: the intention appears to be that the term of the President should synchronize with the life of the Municipality existing or extended, as the case may be. In our view, therefore, the order of the High Court is not correct and the same is set aside.

holdings.text: the second proviso is not attracted to the instant case, as there was no order or notification issued under s. 25 or any other relevant section of the Act extending the term of the councillors fixed under s. 25 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: If that be the legal effect of s. 3 of the Maharashtra Act, the second proviso is not attracted to the instant case, as there was noorder or notification issued under s. 25 or any other relevant section of the Act extending the term of the councillors fixed under s. 25 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extension under s.3 Maharashtra Act is external fiction, not 'under this Act' via notification or order under s.25

holdings.text: approach the problem on the basis of the fiction that the term of the councillors prescribed under s. 25 of the Act was extended up to December 31, 1965

anchor.surface_text: Therefore for the present purpose we leave out of consideration the second proviso to s. 19 and approach the problem on the basis of the fiction that the term of the councillors prescribed under s. 25 of the Act was extended up to December 31, 1965.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3 creates statutory fiction deeming extension of term under s.25 for interpretive purposes

holdings.text: The intention of the Municipality can be gathered only from the circumstances, statutory or otherwise existing at the time when the resolution was passed and on the express terms of the said resolution

anchor.surface_text: The intention of the Municipality can be gathered only from the circumstances, statutory or otherwise existing at the time when the resolution was passed and on the express terms of the said resolution. Under s. 19 of the Act, the Municipality can fix the term of office of the President between one and four years

holdings.reasoning_summary: Resolution interpreted based on contemporaneous statutory context and express language, not post hoc changes

holdings.text: on July 18, 1964, when the Municipal councillors passed a resolution to the effect that the term of office of the appellant shall be the residue of the Municipality, their intention was [not] that his term should extend only up to February 17, 1965

anchor.surface_text: If that be so, the next question is whether on July 18, 1964, when the Municipal councillors passed a resolution to the effect that the term of office of the appellant shall be the residue of the Municipality, their intention was that his term should extend only up to February 17, 1965, i.e., the date when the term of the Municipal councillors would have expired but for the statutory extension given by the Maharashtra Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Councillors knew of possible extension under Act; used elastic 'residue' instead of fixed date

holdings.text: With the knowledge of such a possible extension, when the members used the elastic expression residue, it is not reasonable to attribute to them the intention that they meant only the residue of the term available to them at that time

anchor.surface_text: With the knowledge of such a possible extension, when the members used the elastic expression residue, it is not reasonable to attribute to them the intention that they meant only the residue of the term available to them at that time. If that was their intention they would have prescribed a definite date

holdings.reasoning_summary: Elastic language and avoidance of fixed date indicate intent to include potential extension

holdings.text: the councillors clearly expected that the term of the Municipality would be or could be extended and with that knowledge they passed the resolution fixing the term of the President for the residue of the term of the Municipality

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear that -on the basis of statutory and other circumstances obtaining at the time the extension was made, the councillors clearly expected that the term of the Municipality would be or could be extended and with that knowledge they passed the resolution fixing the term of the President for the residue of the term of the Municipality

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of govt committee (1963), municipality's own resolution (Jul 1964) recommending extension shows expectation

holdings.text: the intention appears to be that the term of the President should synchronize with the life of the Municipality existing or extended, as the case may be

anchor.surface_text: the intention appears to be that the term of the President should synchronize with the life of the Municipality existing or extended, as the case may be. In our view, therefore, the order of the High Court is not Correct and the same is set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive construction aligns president's term with municipality's actual life including statutory extensions

anchor.surface_text: In our view, therefore, the order of the High Court is number Correct and the same is set aside. A writ will issue prohibiting the Collector from holding the election of the President of the Municipality of the Bhusaval Boro

outcome.relief_summary: Order of the High Court set aside. Writ prohibiting the Collector from holding the election of the President till December 31, 1965
directions: A writ will issue prohibiting the Collector from holding the election of the President of the Municipality of the Bhusaval Borough till December 31, 1965

anchor.surface_text: The intention of the Municipality can be gathered only from the circumstances, statutory or otherwise existing at the time when the resolution was passed and on the express terms of the said resolution. anchor.surface_text: If that be so, the next question is whether on July 18, 1964, when the Municipal councillors passed a resolution to the effect that the term of office of the appellant shall be the residue of the Municipality, their intention was that his term should extend only up to February 17, 1965, i.e., the date when the term of the Municipal councillors would have expired but for the statutory extension given by the Maharashtra Act.

In our view, therefore, the order of the High Court is number Correct and the same is set aside. A writ will issue prohibiting the Collector from holding the election of the President of the Municipality of the Bhusaval Boro

anchor.surface_text: With the knowledge of such a possible extension, when the members used the elastic expression residue, it is not reasonable to attribute to them the intention that they meant only the residue of the term available to them at that time. If that was their intention they would have prescribed a definite date

In our view, therefore, the order of the High Court is number Correct and the same is set aside. A writ will issue prohibiting the Collector from holding the election of the President of the Municipality of the Bhusaval Boro
